citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Washington, DC - Impervious Proximity Gradient

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research and Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract: In any given 1-square meter point in this EnviroAtlas dataset, the value shown gives the percentage of impervious surface within 1 square kilometer centered over the given point. Water is shown as '-99999' in this dataset to distinguish it from land areas with low impervious. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: The purpose of this data is to show the density of impervious surface throughout the EnviroAtlas community boundary and the gradients of change in the amount of impervious surface. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html

procstep.procdesc: Begin with EnviroAtlas 1-meter Land Cover for the EnviroAtlas community
Reclassify the Land Cover into Binary Impervious. (Impervious - 20 = 1; All Else = 0)
Compute Focal Statistics on the Impervious Binary with 1001 pixel wide by 1001 pixel high rectangular window with statistics type = sum.
Reclassify the Focal Statistics into 5 classes at 20% intervals.
Create a water binary from the 1-M EnviroAtlas Land Cover. (Water - 10 = 1; All Else = 0).
Run the region group tool to group waterbodies together with options number of neighbors to use: EIGHT, zone grouping method: WITHIN, and ADD_LINK (add link field to output).

Using the region group output, burn water bodies over 300m2 into the impervious percent raster using a conditional statement if Region Group Count > 299 AND Link = 1; for true: -99999; for false: impervious percent raster
Convert the raster into Esri GRID format
Clip the EnviroAtlas Community Boundary to the county lines for the community to limit the output to land area.
Split the raster into pieces of no more than 40,000x40,000 pixels.
Convert each of the raster pieces into a polygon feature class.
Clip the polygon feature classes to the clipped EnviroAtlas community boundary.
Dissolve each piece based on grid_code.
Project the feature class into Albers.
Copy the feature class to the final geodatabase.

enttyp.enttypd: Percentage of impervious surface per square kilometer.

attr.attrdef: Percent impervious area within 1 square kilometer.

overview.eaover:
For more information about EnviroAtlas data, go to https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets.
This layer shows the percentage of impervious surface per square kilometer at any point within the EnviroAtlas Community Boundary.
Processing steps were completed using Python scripts. A comprehensive list of metric creation steps is included in the Processing Steps.
